SHAPE: Rough
COLOR: Blue
HARDNESS: 7-7.5
ORIGIN: blue
TREATMENT: Unheated / Untreated
ShortDescription:
Tourmaline

Although it has been known since ancient times in the Mediterranean region, the Dutch began importing them in 1703 from Sri Lanka. They named it Sinhalese "Turamali" - stone with mixed colors.

A very characteristic feature of tourmaline is the readiness with which it becomes electrified. By heating and subsequently cooling, as well as applying pressure, e.g. by rubbing, a tourmaline crystal will become electrically charged. It will then attract dust particles and small pieces of paper (pyro and piezoelectricity).

(Ca,K,Na)(Al,Fe,Li,Mg,Mn)3 (Al,Cr,Fe,V)6(BO3)3(Si,Al,B)6O18(OH,F)
meta-description: Blue rough Tourmaline 6.20gr (18.7x14x13.5mm) from blue - Not treated

Name: Grandidierite 1.59gr
Description:
Product Details
GEM TYPE: Grandidierite
TOTAL WEIGHT: 1.59gr
SIZE : (LxWxH): 16.4x9.1x6.5mm
SHAPE: Rough
COLOR: Blue
HARDNESS: 7.5
ORIGIN: Madagascar
TREATMENT: Unheated / Untreated
ShortDescription:
Grandidierite
Grandidierite is a very rare mineral that was first discovered in southern Madagascar in the early 20th century. As Grandidierite is quite hard, the high quality material has been cut as gems, making it one of the rarest gems.
Gemologically, grandidierite is a magnesium aluminum borosilicate. It has a hardness of 7 to 7.5 on the Mohs scale, similar to garnet, and a refractive index of 1.590-1.623.

It forms in the orthorhombic crystal system. Grandidierite is typically bluish-green in color and derives its distinctive color from traces of iron. The gemological material is translucent to transparent. Completely transparent samples are absolutely rare.
meta-description: Blue rough Grandidierite 1.59gr (16.4x9.1x6.5mm) from Madagascar - Not treated

HARDNESS: 6-6.5
ORIGIN: Jaen
TREATMENT: Unheated / Untreated
ShortDescription:
Prehnite

It is named in honor of Hendrik von Prehn, governor of the Cape of Good Hope (South Africa) in 1774 who discovered this mineral. The name was coined by the famous German geologist Gottlob Werner in 1788.

They usually appear in a botryoidal habit - globular external shape and resembling a bunch of grapes (where the name derives from the Greek).

Ca2Al(AlSi3O10)(OH)2
meta-description: Green rough Prehnite 25gr (35.3x34.3x21mm) from Jaen - Not treated

Name: Topaz 8.80gr
Description:
Product Details
GEM TYPE: Topaz
TOTAL WEIGHT: 8.80gr
SIZE : (LxWxH): 23.7x21.5x14.5mm
SHAPE: Rough
COLOR: Orange
HARDNESS: 8
ORIGIN: Pakistan
TREATMENT: Unheated / Untreated
ShortDescription:
Topaz

The name is believed to come from 'topazos' - 'seek/hard to find'.

This name, "Topazos" was originally used to name the mineral we now know as Peridot. The first peridot gems came from 'Topazos' island, now called 'Zeberget' island in the Red Sea. It was a difficult island to find and very protected.

Topaz is an allochromatic gem, which means that its color is given by certain elements outside its formula that were introduced into the crystal lattice during its formation. In its pure form it would be colorless.

Al2SiO4(OH,F)2
meta-description: Orange rough Topaz 8.80gr (23.7x21.5x14.5mm) from Pakistan - Not treated
